texts.en: Sod S., 45, is married with five children. He resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, with his wife (in photo) and children. To make a living, he and his wife are engaged in the agriculture sector of growing morning glories (a kind of vegetable), earning approximately US$3 each per day. This source of income from Sod S. and his wife helps cover the family expenses especially for the children’s education in the future. The family is also assisted by two of his children who are working in different workplaces. S. and his wife are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase morning glory seeds and wooden pillows to grow more morning glories to meet his customers’ demand.

loans.use: To buy seeds and wooden pillows to grow more morning glories.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph C. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. He is 22 years old and single. To make a living, Joseph owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joseph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Joseph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Seang

texts.en: Seang S., 45, is married with five children. He resides in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia with his wife (in photo) and children. To make a living, he and his wife are engaged in the agriculture sector of growing morning glories (a kind of vegetable), earning collectively an income of US $19 per day. This source of income from S. and his wife helps cover the family expenses especially for the children’s education in the future. The family is also assisted by one of the children who works as a chef at a restaurant. S. and his wife are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached to transport morning glories to sell at the markets.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a trailer to transport morning glories for sale.

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Eang N., 48, is married with a child. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband. To make a living, she is engaged in the agriculture sector, growing rice, and she rents a plot of land for a phone company, earning an income of US $3 per day. Her husband is also a rice farmer, and he plants several types of vegetables, earning an income of US $2 per day. These sources of income from N. and her husband help cover the family expenses.

N. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, N. is asking for a loan of US $1000 to start a new business selling groceries.

loans.use: buy groceries to start a new business

loans.name: Huk

texts.en:
Huk S., 50, is married with two children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, with her husband and children. To make a living, she is engaged in a business selling fish at a local market in the town, earning an income of US $3 per day. Her husband helps his wife in the business, and he is also a skillful fisherman at the great lake in Cambodia (Tonle Sap Lake), earning an income of US $2.50 per day. These sources of income from S. and her husband help cover the family expenses.

S. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $700 to purchase a motorbike for one of her children to commute to work easily.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for one of her children to commute to work

loans.name: Molly's Group

texts.en:
K. Molly is a friendly and a hard-working businesswoman operating from Kifunjo Cell. She is involved in agriculture as well as having a retail shop for the past 6 years, and she is able to make some good profits that help her to take care of her family and children since she is a widow. She has business challenges of lacking of enough working capital plus the lack of manageable transport for her produce to the market; however, she is much favored by the strategic location of her business in the city centre.

Molly has a dream of expanding her business further, educating her children, plus being rich. She needs a loan to help expand her businesses so that she will be able to get school fees for her children since 2 are at the university, 1 in senior Two, while the last born is in Primary Seven vacation. Molly is the leader of her lending group in Kihihi.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce for resale and restocking her retail shop

loans.name: Lass

texts.en:
Lass P., 54, is a low-income woman living in an area where there are many Islamic people, in Cambodia. To earn a living, Lass P. sells dry fish in the busy local market and typically generates an income US$ 3 each day to meet her family’s daily living expenses. She also buys fresh fish and turns them into dried fish and sells them retail to her regular customers who come to buy things in the market. Her husband earns money by providing a taxi service.

This couple has three children, one of whom is married and the other two single; both are employed in a garment factory. In the past, Lass P. hired a rental shop inside the market to sell her fish and she hopes to own a shop in order to cut down on rental cost. That is why she requested a loan of US$ 1000.

loans.use: To buy a shop

loans.name: Oddo's Group

texts.en:
K. Oddo is the leader of his lending group in Kihihi. He is 38 years old and married with 4 children, all in primary school, as he takes care of his elderly parents. He has been a farmer in Kifunjo parish for 7 years and it is from this that he is able to support his family and expand his business.

Currently, Oddo has a challenge of shortage of farmland plus the diseases that attack his crops although he still wants to expand. He works hard to educate his children for a better future. Oddo needs a loan to help expand his business by buying farming equipment like hoes and 'panga's plus seeds and pesticides and others.

loans.use: Buying farming equipment like hoes, 'panga's, seeds and pesticides

loans.name: Nan

texts.en:
Mrs. Nan M. is 44 years old and a grocery seller. Nan M. has been selling her goods since early 2005 and normally earns US$ 2.50 a day to feed her family. She is married with four children, all four of whom are no longer in school. All four of her children are employed: two are workers in Malaysia and one is a garment worker in Phnom Penh.

As another source of family income, her husband’s business provides a taxi service. Nan M. is taking out her loan to accumulate more grocery inventory to sell and to repair her old house. Note: Nan M.'s was not available when the photo was taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: To accumulate more grocery inventory to sell and to repair her old house

loans.name: Jaka's Group

texts.en:
B. Jaka is the leader of his lending group in Kihihi. He is 43 years old and married with 10 children, of whom 4 are in school, as he takes care of other orphans. Jaka is friendly and hard-working, dealing in agriculture mostly in the selling and buying of green bananas and tea leaves from Mayanja Cell for the past 22 years. He is able to make 700,000/= as profit a month. He is grateful that he was able to secure a good location for his business hence attracting more customers. His motive is to become very rich to the advantage of his family.

Jaka needs a loan to help with buying more tea leaves for resale; his previous loans have helped him with paying his wages on time.

loans.use: Buying more tea leaves for resale

loans.name: Cecilia's Group

texts.en:
Cecilia R. is from the village of Villa Luna, Cauayan City. She is 23 years old. Cecilia is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Cecilia is single. To make a living, Cecilia owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Cecilia is just starting this business.

In 2009, Cecilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cecilia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Cecilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda C. is currently in the business of selling food in a little restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock beer and soft drinks like sodas, packed juice, water, etc. to sell. Rhoda is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up another bigger restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock beer and soft drinks like sodas, packed juice, water, etc.

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario S. Sr. is from the village of Tamucco Sto. Niño Cagayan. He is 44 years old. Mario is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Mario operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Mario has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 50,000 Php during harvest season.

In 2008, Mario joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mario is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the second loan taken out by Mario from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Bujengwe Group A, Kihihi

texts.en:
T. Lydia is 37 years old and married with nine children aged 20 – 3 years; she also takes care of her parents and six orphans, all in Mayanja Cell. Lydia has been in agriculture for 12 years and her major challenges have been the lack of labour (since most times, everybody works on their own farm and very few are left for paid labour) plus her limited capital. She is able to make 300,000/= a month as profits from the sale of tea which helps in boosting her business.

Lydia always ensures that her customer care skills are good; the location of her business is good, and there is a ready market for her produce plus it is high quality. She hopes to expand her business and educate her children further in addition to having a family with good health. Lydia needs a loan to help with the rehabilitation of her tea plantation so that she can increase her income and be able to pay wages efficiently.

loans.use: Rehabilitating her tea plantation for better produce

In 2007, Maribel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI, she is requesting a new loan, her third, of 10000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. Maribel plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

loans.name: Jeny May

texts.en:
Jeny May L., from Labo Ozamiz City, is 24 years old, married, and the mother of an infant. To make a living, Jeny May prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. Engaged in her business for over a year, she earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jeny May joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to invest in expanding the business, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Arevshat

texts.en:
Arevshat M. lives in Sevan with his wife and a son.

Arevshat is a cook and he worked in different restaurants in his specialty for about ten years. In 2007 he decided to open his own catering trade in a rented place, the rent of which is 150,000 AMD per month. With the profit from his business Arevshat provides for his family’s and for his business’s needs. His wife and son help him in this business.

Up to now, Arevshat has served his clients in a big common restaurant room. Now he needs a $2,000 loan to convert a part of his restaurant room into several separate rooms which will increase the client flow to his restaurant.

loans.use: To convert a part of his restaurant into several separate rooms

loans.name: Gune

texts.en:
Gune U. is currently in the business of selling bread in the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of beans and rice to sell.  Gune is 35 years old and is married to a soldier. She has five children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia V. is from the town of Turod Norte Cordon. She is 42 years old and married with two adult children. To make a living, Leticia owns and operates a general store. She sells a variety of different products in the local community. Leticia earns approximately $100 a month from this activity.

In 2009, Leticia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Leticia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

loans.name: Thomas Tangai

texts.en:
Thomas Tangai, 44, is married to Dorcas, 33, who is a businesswoman. They have four children, ages 12, 10, 8 and 6. 

Thomas is a "jack of all trades" when it comes to business. He runs a greengrocer stand in the open air market at Kangemi, and he also runs two other businesses: a café and a tailoring shop.  He makes a profit of about $330 a month from all his businesses. His grocery business is strategically placed and normally very busy. He says that within 30 minutes he can serve up to 15 customers.

Thomas had never borrowed from another MFI (micro-finance institution), but he was introduced to Kadet by a friend who is a member. He has just applied for his first loan, which he plans to use to add more groceries to his greengrocer stand, to restock his café, to buy more materials for his tailoring shop, and he also wants to buy cereals to sell in his greengrocer business. 

In the future, he hopes to get into the transport business and also to farm for his grocery stand.

loans.use: He wants to restock all his businesses; more groceries for his store, restock items in the cafe and materials for his tailoring shop.

loans.name: Ophelia

texts.en:
Ophelia P. is from the town of Turod Norte, Cordon. She is 46 years old and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Ophelia owns and operates a business selling cosmetics products. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $75 a month.

In 2009, Ophelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Ophelia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to buy more products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Kasifa

texts.en:
Kasifa is a 39-year-old single mother of four children between the ages of 11 and 17. All her children go to school. She rents a one-room house where she lives with five people. Kasifa takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and gets three meals a day, but has no piped water. She incurs transportation costs to and from shopping in Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala city.

Kasifa has a retail shop in Natete and sells all types of goods like salt, sugar, flour and soap. She pays rent of about $27 a month for her business premises and about $16 a month for her residence. She works in a semi-urban area which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people.

Her largest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and monthly rent for her business and her residence. Her major business challenges are seasonality and the rainy season which hinders her customers from reaching her.

Kasifa has been in this business for four years and with MCDT for five years, now servicing her 10th loan and working with the same group mates. Kasifa joined MCDT because it was near her home and it was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise, like bags of sugar, cartons of salt and boxes of soap. She wants to see her business grow bigger and would like to start selling on a wholesale basis only.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of salt, bags of sugar and boxes of soap

loans.name: Melba

texts.en:
Melba R. is from the town of Turod Norte Cordon. She is 55 years old, widowed and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Melba owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Melba has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 4000 PHP per month for these activities.

In 2009, Melba joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Melba is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Melba from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Baneru A. runs a business selling charcoal in the local market. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to sell. Baneru is 28 years old and is married to a business man. She has three children and all of her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land and build a house, which she would rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is 41 years old. She is married with seven children between the ages of 15 and 19 years. None of her children go to school because she couldn’t raise school fees. She owns a four-room house, where she is staying with six people. Rehema takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity, gets three meals a day, but do not have piped water. 

Rehema has a stall selling fresh foods in Nakulabye. She incurs transport costs to and from buying her fresh food, such as sacks of bananas, sweet potatoes, cassava, onions and tomatoes. She works seven days a week in a semi urban area, which is on the outskirts of Kampala. She receives an average of 20 customers a day and sells to all categories of people both on the retail and wholesale markets. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding her family, school fees for her children and monthly market dues. Her major business challenge is the rainy season which hinders her from reaching her customers. She has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for five years. Rehema is servicing her tenth loan and working with the same groupmates. Rehema joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of banana, sacks of cassava, boxes of tomatoes and onions. She would like to see her business grower bigger and to be able to sell only on the wholesale market.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Mely

texts.en:
Mely A., from the village of Tamucco Sto. Niño, Cagayan, is 42 years old, married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Mely plants and harvests corn for sale. Engaged in her business for over 15 years, she earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Mely joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting a new loan, her second, of 33000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Mrs. Chhem C., age 37, is a local tailor who has been skilled in the enterprise since 2004, sewing both traditional and modern clothes for men and ladies who need them for parties and ceremonies. Her husband ( who appears in the picture above) is a Khmer musician who plays for wedding parties. The family lives with their two children, both of whom attend the local public school. Chhem C.'s husband now needs more instruments to perform his musical services, so she is requesting a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL.  She purposes to use the rest of the loan to buy an old vehicle for her traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy Khmer instruments and a vehicle for traveling needs.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan S. is from the village of Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 35 years old, married, and has one school-aged child.

Jonathan owns and operates a business providing transportation services to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Jonathan joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business.

Jonathan is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used for the repair and maintenance of his transport vehicle to be able to have a good transportation services. This loan will be his third loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement his family's income.

loans.name: Hamida

texts.en:
Hamida is a 29-year-old married woman with one child aged 10 years. Her child goes to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she lives with three people. She also takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water and gets three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her child and the monthly rent of her residence.

Hamida works seven days a week in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She fries chapati (an unleavened flatbread, similar to tortillas) and samosas (fried or baked triangular-shaped pastry shells with a savory filling) in Kawempe Kalule Zone. She receives an average of twenty customers a day and sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She incurs transport costs to and from buying baking flour and cooking oil for making chapati and samosas. Her major business challenges are seasonality and the rainy season which hinders her from reaching her customers.

Hamida has been in this business for five years and with MCDT for seven years and is servicing her nineteenth loan. Hamida joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. She wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of baking flour and a jerrycan of cooking oil.. She wants to see her business  grower bigger and to start selling wholesale only.

Sak B. hopes to improve her commerce but she doesn’t have enough capital yet to make that possible. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of US$1,000 which will allow her to purchase larger quantities of merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Sony

texts.en:
Mr. Sony N., 46, and his wife Mrs. Yeang Mok, 42, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1991 and have three children, all of whom are in school.

Sony is a mason in his village and a nearby province. His wife has been a tailor since 1990. He is requesting a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase additional clothes and finished silk fabrics for his wife to continue expanding her tailoring business.

loans.use: To buy additional clothes and finished silk fabrics for his wife's business

loans.name: Sut

texts.en: Sut E. is a 48-year-old cultivator, a married mother of three young children. Sut E. was not available for a photograph so her husband is pictured instead. Sut E. is married to Sgoun Vinh, age 47, who is a construction worker. Sut E. hopes to make extra income by using her loan to order rice to resell at a profit.

loans.use: To order rice to resell

loans.name: Reem

texts.en:
Reem is a twenty-six year-old Palestinian woman, married with four children. She and her husband own a bakery shop where they sell sweets like cakes, cookies, Swiss roll, eclairs, etc. Their business is located at Al-Najah University street, a very bustling area in Nablus city Northern West Bank. Nablus is considered the commercial capital for the West Bank and it is the biggest Palestinian city.

Reem and her husband started this business six years ago and it is growing very fast. They both work very hard in this business as it is the only source of income for the family. Reem's husband is involved in the baking and decoration of the sweets while she sells the products to the customers in the shop.

Reem and husband requested 3000 USD from FATEN to buy raw materials as demand is high for sweets during the holiday season. Reem's husband appears in the picture while preparing some sweets.

loans.use: Buy raw materials for producing sweets

loans.name: Mong

texts.en: Mrs. T. is a vegetable farmer living in the rural area of Siem Reap province. T. is a young mother blessed with two kids, who are already enrolled in primary school. T. is looking for a loan to buy a vehicle (motorbike) for her husband to ride to his work at the construction site.

loans.use: To buy a vehicle (motorbike)

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. Srey K. (shown in the picture), 49, has been married to her new husband for nine years. She has one daughter who is a garment factory worker. The family lives in a small village outside of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Srey has been selling rice and food in front of her house for almost two years. She is able to earn 20,000.00 riel/day (about 5 USD). She is in the process of building a fence around her house, but she doesn’t have enough money to finish it. Hence Srey is requesting her first loan of US$ 1,000 to finish the fence and she will use a part of the loan to build a kitchen where she can cook.

loans.use: To build a fence around her house and build a kitchen where she cooks

loans.name: Ean

He is married to Cham Chorn, 30, a local crop grower, and they have three school-aged children who are dependent on them. Since Ean incurs high transportation costs commuting to work because he doesn’t have his own vehicle, he is requesting a loan to add to his own small savings to buy a used motorbike which he will use to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike

texts.en:
Irene Z. is from the town of Turod Norte in the municipality of Cordon on Luzon. She is 54 years old and single. Irene raises livestock to sell, primarily pigs. Irene has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 2000 PHP whenever she sells her animals.

Irene joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Irene is requesting a loan, her first, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use any additional revenue to grow her business.

About ASKI:

loans.name: Ham

texts.en:
Ham S., 43, has run a taxi service in his community for a long time. He earns $4 a day with his taxi. Before starting his work, he also goes to buy fish for his wife to sell at the market. Ham is a good father who cares for his six dependent children.

Ham S. wishes to apply for a loan to use as additional capital to buy more fish for his wife to sell.

loans.use: To buy more fish for his wife to sell at market.

loans.name: Roel

texts.en:
Roel P. is from the village of Bonfal Proper, part of the municipality of Bayombong and within Nueva Vizcaya province on Luzon. He is 41 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Roel provides motorcycle taxi transportation to local community members. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Roel joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Roel is requesting a loan, his third from ASKI, of 8000 PHP (he has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI) for additional inventory and working capital to support his business. He plans to use any additional revenue to pay his children’s tuition fees.

About ASKI (Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc.):

loans.name: Améyo

texts.fr: Cette femme est une dame très dynamique qui a commencé depuis 1999 le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale. Son mari est un soudeur et son revenu ne couvre pas toutes les charges de la famille. Avec son commerce elle contribue financièrement aux charges de sa famille. Actuellement son stock a connu une baisse elle voudrait se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de  4 bidons d’huile, 2 cartons moyen de sucre, 4 boîtes de tomates en conserve et divers produits d’alimentation générale.
texts.en:
This woman is a very dynamic lady who began selling general grocery products in 1999. Her husband is a welder and his income does not cover all the family's expenses. With her business she makes a financial contribution to the household expenses. At present her stock has diminished and she would like to build it up again; for this reason she is asking for a loan from WAGES for the purchase of 4 cans of oil, 2 medium-sized boxes of sugar, 4 tins of tomatoes and other general groceries.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of general groceries

loans.name: Bunthoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Bunthoeun T., 47, and his wife, Mrs. Neang Kim, 45, (both are shown in the photo) have been married since 1983. They have eight children: three sons and five daughters. Two of the children are married and live outside the family home, another two are garment factory workers, three attend school and the other one stays at home.

Bunthoeun has been driving a motor taxi for more than ten years, while his wife is a cleaner for a company. Unhappily, a thief stole his motorbike so that Bunthoeun is not able to continue his business. Facing this, he decides to request his first loan of $1,000 to buy a new motorbike in order to continue his business.

It is difficult for him to find a proper place to keep things in the open-air space on the ground beneath his house, and things there are exposed to the elements. Therefore, he will use a part of the loan to build a concrete and brick room under his wooden house.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to continue his motor taxi business and to build a concrete room under his wooden house

loans.name: Abla

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce comme activité la vende d’œufs et de divers produits d’alimentation générale. Elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 1999, elle s’approvisionne en produits d’alimentation générale à Lomé et en œufs dans une ferme à l’intérieur du pays.  Son stock de marchandises est en baisse elle voudrait se réapprovisionner et  sollicite par conséquent de WAGES un crédit pour l’achat de 15 plateaux d’œufs et divers produits d’alimentation générale. 
Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, avec  son commerce elle contribue aux dépenses de sa famille.
texts.en:
This woman runs a business selling eggs and other general foodstuffs. She began this business in 1999 and stocks up on general foodstuffs in Lomé and on eggs at a farm inland. Her stock of goods is declining and she would like to build it up again; she is thus asking for a loan from WAGES for the purchase of 15 trays of eggs and other general foodstuffs. She is married and has two children; through her business she contributes to the household expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 15 trays of eggs

loans.name: Bienvenida

texts.en:
Bienvenida R. is from the village of Migpange Bonifacio Misamis Occ. She is 45 years old. Bienvenida is married and has 4 school-aged children. Bienvenida owns & operates a business that sells seafood products including fish, shrimp, and crabs in the local community. Bienvenida has been in business for over 3 years and makes a monthly income of approximately 4,500 Philippine pesos (PHP), which is about $97 US.

In 2008, Bienvenida joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bienvenida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Bienvenida is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children and to pay for daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

Jaypee has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP during harvest season.

Jaypee is requesting a new loan of 16000 PHP which will be used to purchase general agricultural supplies & equipment. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jaypee from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of the borrower's family.

loans.name: Elise

texts.fr: O. Elise est née en 1969 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Elise réside à Djègan-Kpèvi, dans le quatrième arrondissement de Porto-Novo, depuis 8 ans. Mariée à YEHOUENOU Pierre, Elise est mère de deux enfants. Aucun des enfants n'est scolarisé. Elise vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Elise n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Elise vend de l'igname frit et également de l'huile de palme dans son quartier. Elise s'approvisionne au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. C'est depuis 5 ans que Elise mène cette activité. Elise a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement afin d'agrandir son activité pour mieux répondre à la demande de la clientèle, Elise sollite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Elise O. was born in 1969 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Elise has lived in Djègan-Kpèvi in the fourth "arrondissement" or district of Porto-Novo for 8 years. Married to Pierre YEHOUENOU, Elise has two children. Neither of the children is at school. Elise lives with her children and her husband. The couple together support the family financially. Elise has not been to school. In order to meet her needs, Elise sells fried yam as well as palm oil in her neighbourhood. Elise stocks up at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She has been running this business for 5 years. Elise has already taken out two loans from ALIDé and these loans have been repaid without problem. With a view to increasing her working capital in order to expand her business and better satisfy customer demand, Elise is asking for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of yam

She has 6 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children and build them a permanent house.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. loans.name: Mustapha

texts.en: Mustapha K. has a drug store with a class C License which enables him to sell essential drugs.  He started this business eleven years ago as a drug peddler. He has constructed a small store along the main road to provide convenient storage facility for the drugs. Mustapha is married and has two children. His store is open for seventeen hours every day and his wife provides the necessary support to run the store. Now ideally located, he wants to increase his stock and hire a druggist on a part-time basis so that he can be qualified to include controlled but essential drugs to his stock items.  Mustapha is intelligent and determined, he wants to construct a small house for his family in the future.

texts.en:
Maria A. is from Linao Norte, Tuguegarao City. She is 55 years old, married, and has eight adult-aged children.

Maria owns and operates a business venture into planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables and fruits for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities.

Maria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fifth loan taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to sustain the family's income. 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Chandiru

texts.en:
Chandiru J. is currently in the business of selling food at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock drinks like water, boxed juices and sodas to sell. Chandiru is 40 years old and married to a peasant. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a big hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock drinks like water, boxed juice and sodas to sell

loans.name: Kunthy

texts.en:
Kunthy L., 29, is single and lives on an island in the Mekong River with her grandfather and her mother, who is a silk weaver. Her home is approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Kunthy has been a silk weaver since she was fourteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market.

The space under her house where she weaves is small, which makes weaving difficult for her. Therefore, Kunthy is applying for her first loan of $350 to build a shelter in front of her house. After the renovations, she will be able to weave more comfortably.

loans.use: To build a shelter in front of her house where she weaves.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida T. is from the village of Salay, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old and a widow with two school-aged children. To make a living, Aida owns and operates retail store where she buys and sells used clothing, known as ukay ukay, in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $125 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Aida joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation by engaging in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Aida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Am

texts.en:
Am Y. T., age 45, resides in the best part of Kampong Chhnang which is a good location for farming. Am Y. T. has been a farmer for a long time. Besides her farming business, she is a civil servant officer working in the ministry of planning. She is married and has three school-aged children. Her husband raises pigs and also provides a taxi service to earn a living.

Am Y. T. needs a loan to use for various proposes; such as, to pay her children’s school fees, to buy more pig food and piglets to raise and to repair an existing motorcycle.

Note: Am Y. T. was not available at the time so her husband is pictured instead.

loans.use: to pay her children’s school fees, to buy more pig food and piglets to raise, and to repair a motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy J. is currently in the business of selling used clothes in the market and is requesting a loan to buy a new supply of clothing to sell.  Joy is 30 years old and married to an engineer. She has three children and they all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a boutique.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy a new supply of clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Maika

texts.en:
Maika B. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste in a market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of groundnuts for making paste to sell. Maika is 36 years old and is divorced. She has four children and they all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a beauty salon.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock more bags of groundnuts for making paste to sell.

loans.name: Leonita

texts.en:
Leonita C. is from Linao Norte, Tuguegarao City. She is 57 years old, married, and has two adult-aged children.

Leonita owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 250 PHP a day.

In 2005, Leonita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her fifth loan taken out from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to uplift the general living condition of their family . 


About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Vazir

texts.en:
Vazir A. is applying for his second loan from Kiva. The first time he applied for a loan he sold the spare parts and his son, who helped his father, was shown in the photo. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy the five calves to improve his cattle-breeding business.

"I improved my spare parts sales business and now I have a cattle-breeding business. Thank you very much, Kiva Lenders! "

loans.use: To buy five calves

loans.name: Eng

texts.en:
Eng S., 52 years old, is a grocery seller who has been selling her items to her nearby neighbors for years. Beside this income, she also relies on the income from other family members. Her husband works in construction, while one of her children is employed in a garment factory.

Eng S. is applying for a loan to purchase extra grocery inventory for sale.

loans.use: To purchase extra grocery inventory for sale

loans.name: Lourn

texts.en:
Lourn R., 35, is married with three school-aged children. She resides in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia with her husband and children.

R. is engaged in a business selling ground rice at a local market in the province, earning an income of US$8 per day. Her husband helps her in the business, and he operates his motorbike as a taxi driver, earning an income of US$4 per day. These incomes from R. and her husband help cover the family expenses.

R. and her husband are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, R. is asking for a loan of US$600 to purchase a motorbike to transport her ground rice to sell at the markets.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport her ground rice

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn E. lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 35 years old and married with three children. Evelyn sells drinks and Nigerian cooked foods from her stall. She wakes up daily at 4:30 a.m. to start preparing her food for sale. She has been in this business for four years. Evelyn is a hard-working woman determined to lift her business and family out of poverty.

LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. As a LAPO client, Evelyn is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase additional drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To buy additional drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell.

loans.name: Sokleak

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokleak C. has been a textile designer since she was 18 years old – a skill she learned from her mother. She designs patterns for silk fabric. In addition to this business, she also buys finished silk fabrics from the weavers in the village and transports them to sell at other districts far away from her home. Sokleak does not have enough capital to purchase finished silk fabric for resale. That’s why she is applying for her first loan of $500 US in order to increase her capital.

Sokleak (shown in the photo), 29, and her husband, Mr. Poli Pich, 27, were married in 1998 and just have one daughter who attends school. They are living on an island in the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Phnom Penh is the capital city of Cambodia. Her husband is a soldier.

loans.use: To purchase finished silk fabric for resale

loans.name: Fernando

texts.en:
Fernando E. makes a living primarily by operating a tricycle. He is 33 years old, married and has one school-age child. They are from the town of Turod Norte, Cordon. Fernando has been in his business for over seven years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Fernando joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Fernando is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in his business. This will be his first loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand his business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Ebby Mukele

texts.en:
Ebby Muleke is a 46-year-old lady who is married and the mother of four children. Her husband, Johnson A., is 50 years old and an employee of a company that deals with the energy supply in Kenya. Two of her children are employed and one is in college, while the last-born is in the primary level of schooling.

Ebby is a tailor by profession and she specializes in petticoat making. After making the petticoats, she travels to Eldoret town, where she sells them in large quantities. She has been doing this business for the last 10 years and she normally gets a profit of about 20,000 Kenya shillings.

She joined Kadet, a Kiva partner, after an introduction by a friend. She has no previous history of loan financing. This will be her first loan and she plans to use it to add stock for making the petticoats and also for transportation costs.

She is planning to open a shop in Eldoret town and also have a machine and a staff working from there so that she can run two shops, both in Nairobi and Eldoret.

loans.use: Adding material stock for making ladies petticoats

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fish in bulk

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa R. is currently in the business of selling milk in a market and is requesting a loan to purchase more jerry cans of milk to sell. Hawa is 32 years old and single. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase more jerry cans of milk to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana F. lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 28 years old, married and has one child. She is a friendly woman who has been selling sarongs since 2008 to her customers from her stall. She loves this high season because sales will increase, and she will be able to meet the basic needs of her family members.

LAPO (Lift above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa. As a LAPO client, Christiana is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. Christiana wishes to say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Joel's Group

texts.en:
Joel V. is from the village of Centro 2, San Guillermo, Isabela. He is 46 years old. Joel is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Joel is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Joel runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products, such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Joel has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2009, Joel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Joel from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Chhim

texts.en:
Chhim S. is a married woman who is 38 years old. She has been a farmer, a skill she learned from her grandmother, for years. She plants rice and vegetable crops to earn a living. Her husband is a local palm climber who taps palm juice and turns it into palm sugar for selling. 

This couple was married many years ago and has three teenage children. Their children attend school and also help them on the farm when they are free from their classes. 

Chhim S. needs a loan to buy a small piece of her neighbor’s farmland, where she will also grow crops.

loans.use: To buy a small piece of neighbor’s farmland to grow crops on

loans.name: Heshbon Mukanzi

texts.en:
Heshbon Mukazi is a 33-year-old widowed gentleman and father of a 4-year-old girl called Miriam. He operates a printing shop where he also offers services like photocopying and spare parts for the printing machines. He has been operating this shop for the last eight years and he normally gets a monthly profit of 54,000 kenya shillings. His business is strategically placed in a busy area and he has regular customers who come to his shop.

He had borrowed from a micro-finance institution before a member from a group in KADET, a Kiva partner, introduced him to KADET. This will be his first loan from KADET and he will use the money to add more printing materials and to renew his business license.
 
Once he gets enough capital, he plans to open another outlet and expand his business. From his attached photo, he seems quite confident he'll achieve this goal.

loans.use: He wants to renew his business licence and add more stock for his printing shop.

loans.name: Tan

texts.en:
Tan S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She is a farmer and also sells fish at the local market with her husband to earn approximately $10 in revenue each day. She and her husband have been working as farmers and fish sellers since 2004. This couple has three young children living at home to support. 

Tan S. is asking for a loan of $500 she needs to purchase a stock of rice to resell at the local market.

loans.use: Purchase rice to resell

loans.name: Munasib

texts.en:
Munasib is married and has two children. He was born in 1974. This man is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli region, now settled in the Fuzuli region, Zobjug village.

Munasib started his cattle breeding business fifteen years ago. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy four calves to improve his cattle breeding business.

loans.use: To buy four calves

loans.name: Kosal

texts.en:
Mr. Kosal M., 40, and his wife, Mrs. Sovoeun Sok, 39, shown in the photo with their children, live along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1990 and have seven children: two sons and five daughters. Two of the children are assisting their parents with their farming business, four others attend school, and the youngest stays at home.

Kosal and his wife are farmers. They grow many kinds of vegetables such as cauliflowers, bitter gourd and eggplant on their farmland in the village. The couple hopes to increase the volume of their products, so Kosal is asking for a loan of $1,200 to pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide to use on her farm.

loans.use: To pay plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella, who lives in Lagos State, Nigeria, is 29 years old, married with 5 children, all in primary school.  She has been selling VCDs at retail prices from her market stall for the past two years and hopes to be a major VCDs distributor in the future.  Stella is very happy with her family and the growth of her business and hopes for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Tep

texts.en: Tep C., a longtime farming businesswoman, lives in the province of Kampong Chhnang where she also sells a few grocery items to her villagers for extra profit. Tep C. is a single lady and currently resides with her older mother who assists her in growing crops. Because she is very busy with her grocery business due to customer demand, she is requesting a loan to purchase more inventory.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory for her store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Chhem R. is 51 years old and lives with her husband in the Siem Reap province. She and her husband are farmers and raise animals to earn a living. They are able to make a combined amount of about $5 profit every day. Chhem R. is asking for a loan of $500 to purchase fertilizer and rice seed to expand her cultivation.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and rice seed.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa M. is currently in the business of selling rice and beans and is requesting a loan. Hawa is 41 years old and is a widow. She has seven children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock more bags of beans and rice to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase crops in bulk

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: S., age 37, earns a living by selling traditional stoves from her home. She buys the stoves in bulk on credit from her supplier and pays with her income after she has sold them all. She is a divorced mother and blessed with a young child, who goes to the local school. S. is taking out her loan to order to buy more stoves to sell.

loans.use: To order more stoves to sell

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Mrs. Rin L., 53, is a widow with one son and five daughters. Three of them are married and live outside the family home. One daughter is a garment factory worker, and the other children assist their mother in the farming business. They are living along national road number one about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Rin has been a farmer for thirty years. She doesn’t have enough capital to maintain her farm, so she is asking for her first loan of $350 to pay for plowing fees and to purchase fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To pay for plowing fees and to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.name: James Nderitu

texts.en:
James is 32 years old and married to Hellen. They are blessed with two daughters. He has been operating a retail shop for the past five years. He learned about the Kiva partner, KADET, through marketing outreach in his home town of Sagana. James has never borrowed from another MFI (micro-finance institution). James' business is located in a scarcely populated area of middle class people, and as a result the competition is low, which is a big advantage to his business as long as the shop is well stocked.

He is planning to expand his business with the loan he has applied for. He intends to open a cafe, which is under construction, with the extra profit he is expecting from his shop. His hopes and dreams are to educate his children and to improve their standard of living. He describes himself as a hardworking man, creative and faithful.

loans.use: To expand his retail business in Sagana.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom S., 60, is a widow who lives with three of her children in Siem Reap province. To earn a living, she grows rice and raises pigs. On average, she makes about US$2.50 of profit every day. She is also aided by three of her children who are construction workers building houses.

Mom S. is requesting a loan of US$800 to support her children’s needs to buy construction tools. Mom S. was not available for the photo so one of her sons is shown instead.

loans.use: To buy construction tools for her sons

loans.name: Peninah Nyambura

texts.en:
Peninah is married to Jonathan and they have two children, Emmanuel and Zipporah, who are ages 10 and 6 years old respectively.

Peninah was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she has no previous credit history. She intends to use the loan to stock tablecloths to sell to customers in her secondhand clothing business.

Peninah's business is situated in a densely populated area with high competition and she relies on passersby as customers. With the extra profits she will expand her business further and open a retail shop selling new clothes.

Peninah hopes to own a chain of boutique shops in the town one day. She believes she is focused and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy tablecloths and to increase her stock

loans.name: Pasquelina Muthanje

texts.en:
Pasquelina is 38 years old and married to Silvester. They have one son and one daughter.

Pasquelina was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a KADET credit officer. She plans to use her loan to buy raw materials (i.e. trees for timber extraction) for her timber business. She says December is the busiest season for timber sales and furniture sales and she wants to have enough stock for the festive season’s spike in demand. Her business is located in a very busy market place and her customers are mostly carpenters.

Pasquelina intends to continue saving profits generated from the business. Her hope is to purchase a piece of land and to build her own residential house. She describes herself as a hardworking lady, loves her family and is determined to educate her children.

loans.use: To add stock to her timber business

loans.name: Khao

texts.en:
Khao S. is 29 years old and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province. This couple has four children, three of who are students and one is too young to attend school.

Khao S. grows vegetables and raises pigs to earn a living and is able to make about US$3 of profit every day. Her husband is a recycler and make US$4 of profit each day. 

Khao S. is asking for a loan of US$500 to purchase pig feed.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Ujema

texts.en: Ujema J. is currently in the business of selling bed sheets in the market and is requesting a loan to stock new bed sheets to sell. Ujema is 27 years old and is single. She has one child and her child goes to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for her family. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock new bed sheets to sell

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim L., 51, is married and lives with her six children in Siem Reap province. She works in a grocery store, making around US$15 in revenue each day, while her husband grows vegetables and makes US$7 a day.

Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high.

Kim L. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike to transport groceries.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport her groceries

loans.name: Khloak

texts.en:
Khloak D., 30, is a married woman and mother. She retails both new and used clothes that she orders in bulk from wherever they are sold at a reasonable price. She was busy selling her clothes at the market when the photo was taken, so her husband is pictured instead.

Khloak D. is married to Koy Sarim, age 30, who is a motor taxi driver. They have two minor children who are not enrolled in school. 

Khloak D. conducts her investment very smoothly. She has a lot of regular customers who need to buy her clothes because she is skilled in public relations and is very satisfied person.

Khloak D. faces a problem with transporting her clothes to the market because she has no vehicle. Because of that, she decided to request her second loan to purchase a new motorbike which she will use as transportation. With the remainder of the loan she will buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to transport her clothes

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey S. is a married man and the young father of a lovely kid who is still minor and not enrolled in school.

Srey S. owns and operates a small workshop providing a vehicle repair service. Another source of family income comes from his wife’s business selling a few groceries from home.

Srey S. has been building his new house for a long time but the construction has been suspended due to the lack of money. In order to help finish building his house he has decided to request a loan from Kiva’s partner HKL.

loans.use: To help finish building his house

loans.name: Naser

texts.en:
Naser is married with 7 children. Three of them are day workers in Israel and the others are in school. His business is cutting and re-shaping West Bank mountain stones used in construction — for example in stairs or around kitchen windows. Naser has requested 2000 USD from FATEN to prepare the second floor of his house for his eldest son when he gets married; the house is built but needs to be painted. His previous loan from FATEN for his business was fully repaid on time.

Naser is shown at the FATEN office.

loans.use: Home renovation

location.town: Ektaba village, Tulkarem City, West Bank

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase shop items in bulk

loans.name: Voice Of Women Group

texts.en:
These are members of the Voice of Women group. They are small-scale businesswomen in Makeni city who want a loan of SLL 500,000 each to enable them to expand their businesses. This will be their very first loan from SMT/Kiva. With this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their businesses so that they can attract more customers, make better sales, earn more profit and improve on their living standard. 

Adama F. in the middle is the leader of this group. Adama is now age forty-seven. She was born in Makeni and is  a widow with six children. Two of her children are already adults, three are in secondary school, and one is in class six. 

Adama sells market foods such as Maggi (used to give sauce a good flavor), salt, onions, tomatoes etc. wholesale. With her share of the loan, she will add more goods to her business. She will buy more cartons of Maggi, more bags of salt, onions, and tomatoes.

(Attached on the right is the snapshot of a group member who was not present for the group photo).

loans.use: Buy the goods she sells wholesale

loans.name: Suong

texts.en:
Suong D., 35, owns an operates a small grocery shop out of her home. In her shop she sells a variety of cooking ingredients to people who are her nearby villagers.

Suong D. is a divorced woman and has two children; one is married and one single. Both of her children are workers in the garment industry. She currently lives with her older mother who weaves rattan sacks for sale.

Suong D. needs a loan to enlarge her grocery business.

loans.use: To enlarge her grocery business
